gameTheoryNote.title: üéØ Game Theory Framework: "Chicken Game" Dynamics
gameTheoryNote.description: Strategic Assessment: This conflict represents a classic "Chicken Game" where both players race toward each other, neither wanting to retreat first, but both knowing collision would be devastating. Israel cannot allow Iran to reach the nuclear threshold, while Iran cannot afford to appear to be folding for fear of losing prestige and regional leadership.

options.description: B-2 strikes after Trump ultimatum failure

scenarios.description: Game Theory Assessment: Iran's nuclear strategy follows a "slow path" to avoid triggering US/Israeli intervention until the last moment possible. Current dynamics represent strategic restraint, not weakness, but understanding that the next stage may be uncontrollable. Analysis incorporates escalation dominance theory, commitment problems, and asymmetric stakes.
scenarios.chartLegend: Methodology: Game theory analysis incorporating chicken game dynamics, escalation dominance theory, commitment problems, asymmetric stakes, and historical escalation patterns from similar conflicts.

items.title: Limited Escalation & Face-Saving
items.description: Strategic Logic: Both sides seek controlled de-escalation to avoid catastrophic costs while maintaining credibility. Gulf mediation provides face-saving exit ramp. Risk: Chicken game dynamics make retreat signal weakness.

items.title: Controlled Escalation Campaign
items.description: Most Probable: "India-Pakistan model" - exchange of blows with mutual restraint to avoid all-out war. Both sides test limits while maintaining escalation control. Duration: 3-6 months of measured responses.

items.title: Escalation to Regional War
items.description: Miscalculation Risk: Nuclear escalation can occur rapidly once conventional deterrence fails. Triggers: Massive civilian casualties, leadership strikes, or proxy escalation beyond control thresholds.

items.title: Iranian Nuclear Sprint
items.description: Desperation Strategy: Iran's "slow path" strategy accelerates to weapons capability if conventional deterrence fails. Currently at 60% enrichment - can produce weapons-grade in weeks.

items.title: US Military Intervention
items.description: Escalation Dominance: B-2 bombers with MOPs represent only capability to destroy deep underground facilities. Trump's commitment trap and Israeli pressure create intervention pathway.

riskCalculator.intro: Game Theory Analysis: Large conflicts become large because they escalate - fighting is equally likely to escalate as deescalate in any given year. Adjust factors below to model escalation dynamics and commitment problems.

escalationAnalysis.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Escalation Dynamics Analysis
escalationAnalysis.description: Current Risk Level: Large wars become large because they escalate. Stability-instability paradox: Nuclear threats reduce major war probability but increase minor conflicts. Both sides in "competition in risk-taking" where resolve matters as much as capabilities.

timeline.description: Critical decision points where game theory dynamics will determine conflict trajectory

events.title: üéØ Iranian Strategic Response Choice
events.description: Game Theory Moment: Iran must choose between proportional response (maintains chicken game) or massive retaliation (risks escalation dominance by US/Israel). Neither side wants to be first to retreat, but both know collision would be devastating.

events.title: üá∫üá∏ Trump Ultimatum Expiry
events.description: Commitment Trap: Trump's public ultimatum creates domestic credibility stakes. Credible deterrence requires both capability and perceived resolve. B-2 deployment signals escalation dominance preparation.

events.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Escalation Control Assessment
events.description: Strategic Calculation: Escalation dynamics determine whether conflicts grow in severity. Both sides assess whether controlled escalation remains viable or risks spiraling beyond control mechanisms.

events.title: üîÑ Resolution or Entrenchment
events.description: End Game: Either successful face-saving de-escalation through third-party mediation, or acceptance of new "cold war" equilibrium with periodic controlled escalation cycles. Real victory is to prevent the crash, not lead to it.
